PostValue.explanation: This is a routine request for feedback on Rethink Priorities' animal-welfare work. It could modestly affect RP's priorities, methods, and usefulness to the animal-advocacy community if many relevant people respond, but it makes no substantive claims and is not foundational to EA or longtermist reasoning. It is essentially administrative/organisational rather than world-important, and has negligible direct impact on general humanity.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Add clear privacy/consent details — currently there’s no information about anonymity, how responses will be used, whether quotes may be published or attributed, who will have access, data retention, or whether follow‑ups are allowed. Without this people may withhold candid criticism. Action: add a brief sentence (or a one‑line bullet) explaining whether responses are anonymous/confidential, where data is stored, whether you’ll publish aggregated results or quotes, and how respondents can opt out of follow‑up.  

2) Define and screen the eligible population more precisely — the footnote definition (“read any write‑ups…”) is very broad and will likely pull in people with only cursory exposure, which can dilute or bias results. Action: either tighten the definition (e.g., read X report, attended Y event, used RP research in decision‑making) or add 1–2 short screening questions at the start (e.g., level of familiarity, which products/events they engaged with, recency) and plan to stratify/weight responses by familiarity.  

3) Reduce participation friction and increase trust/transparency — the post omits practical details that affect response rates and trust (no info on incentives, no timezone for the deadline, shortened link destination, and no promise to share outcomes). Action: say whether you’re offering payment or not, give the deadline timezone, replace the short URL with the full destination or preview it, and commit to sharing a short public summary of findings and planned changes. These small additions will increase response rates and the usefulness of replies.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies several substantive, actionable flaws that could materially harm response rate, data quality, and ethics: missing privacy/consent details (which can suppress candid criticism), an overly broad eligibility definition (which risks diluting or biasing results), and practical trust/friction issues (incentives, timezone, link transparency, and sharing results). These fixes are compact and feasible to add and would meaningfully improve the post’s effectiveness and credibility.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No notable presence in EA/rationalist communities or in wider public sources up to my 2024-06 knowledge cutoff. Likely a little-known or pseudonymous author with minimal/no recognized publications or citations.

PostClarity.explanation: Clear, well-structured call-to-action: target audience, purpose, link, deadline, and time estimate are all stated and a footnote defines "engaged with." Minor issues: slightly awkward phrasing in places, noisy formatting (bold, emoji, image), and the deadline lacks a year which could cause ambiguity for some readers.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is a routine request for feedback/audience survey from a nonprofit (Rethink Priorities). Asking former readers/attendees to fill an impact survey is a very common practice both within EA circles and more broadly. There are no new arguments, frameworks, or claims — only an outreach/feedback solicitation with minor specifics (targeted audience, deadline, topic area).

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: The post is a clear, coherent call-to-action and reasonably defines who should respond (strength), but it makes implicit claims about the value of feedback without laying out any reasoning or methodological safeguards (weakness). No empirical evidence, sampling plan, survey design, or incentives are provided, so there is little basis to judge how useful or representative the eventual results will be.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Major factual claims in the post are verifiable and accurate: the EA Forum post exists (author Elisa Autric, timestamp Jun 10, 2025), the post includes the bit.ly survey link and a stated deadline of Sunday June 29 (which was Sunday, June 29, 2025), and Rethink Priorities’ description as a “think‑and‑do tank” matches their website/about pages. The only minor points are subjective (the survey '10–25 minutes' estimate) and the shortened link target was not resolved here, so the exact form contents/time-to-complete were not independently confirmed.
sources: Help RP — Fill Out Our Animal Impact Survey! — EA Forum / GreaterWrong mirror (Elisa Autric), 10 Jun 2025 — https://ea.greaterwrong.com/posts/AKBTzQP8LzebzpkZi/help-rp-fill-out-our-animal-impact-survey
Rethink Priorities — homepage ('Rethink Priorities is a think-and-do tank') — https://rethinkpriorities.org/ (organization description and research areas)
Rethink Priorities — Team / About ('A think-and-do tank', established 2018) — https://rethinkpriorities.org/team
Rethink Priorities user page on EA Forum (shows the post in their recent posts list) — https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/users/rethink-priorities
June 2025 calendar (confirms June 29, 2025 was a Sunday) — Calendar-365.com — https://www.calendar-365.com/calendar/2025/June.html
